description: From Latin reclūdere (“to open; to shut off”), from re- + claudere (“to close”).

verbs.description: reclude (third-person singular simple present recludes, present participle recluding, simple past and past participle recluded)

entries.meaning: (transitive, obsolete) To open; to unblock. [15th–19th c.]
(transitive or reflexive) To close off, to confine. [from 16th c.]
(transitive or reflexive) To seclude, cut off from the community, the world etc. [from 16th c.]
examples: And, surely, no woman who knows that of herself can be rightly censured for not recluding herself from the world: it is only women without the power to love who have no right to provoke men's love.
